title: How many forecasters will join the Global Judgment Challenge on Good Judgment Open before 8 January, 2018?
preds: Having Fareed as a spokes person for this challenge, will be a big hit, thus many many signing up.

Cumulative count of first forecasts while “GPS” was on air.
Sunday, 7. January 2018 8am GMT forecast closes
...
10pm GMT, 2363 (+16) joined, 1334 (+87) joined last week 9pm GMT, 2347 [+61 ***] joined, 1247 [+313 ***] joined last week
8pm GMT, 2337 (+51) joined
7pm GMT, 2286 (+17) joined, 934 (+63) joined last week 
6pm GMT, 2269 (+28) joined, 871 (+135) joined last week ---------- on air 5pm GMT, 2241 [+66 ***] joined, 736 [+333 ***] joined last week 
4pm GMT, 2191 (+16) joined
3pm GMT, 2175 (+4) joined, 403 joined last week ---------- on air 2pm GMT, 2171 (+5) joined, 400 joined last week
1pm GMT, 2166 joined. Last week's data, collected by https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/659056
*** over two hours -----------------------
An 80 percent drop in the rate after the first show, today. Last week, there were 5x more joins. Golden Gate, the ends ... And the CNN webpage has not properly linked to this website. @amory10
I believe people will find it interesting enough to want to take part in.
Hunkering down for the surge.  As of 8:30 am PST, need 767 to get over 3,000. That's about 70% of the first show.
With only a few hours left, there are currently approx 2200 participants.
The website is insufficiently user-friendly to make it likely. Most won't follow through and answer all of the questions, either.

Surge time! I downgraded my forecast for "2001-2999" from 93% to 89% 24hr ago, as there had been a slight upswing in hourly joins on Friday evening.  While that short burst makes only a small difference in the final total, it potentially could be (could have been) auspicious regarding the size of the surge. However, most recent 24hr only had 63 new joins, the lowest number of daily joins since 31 Dec. So now we need 843 to join during the next 24hr, or 77% of the 1100 joins in the 24hr following the original telecast.  Bear in mind, of those 1100 joins, more than half of them had happened by 1400 EST, 31 Dec.  In other words, if we don't see a total of 2580 total forecasters by 1400 EST, 7 Dec, it is probably game over. *******************************
EDIT:
_No_ new joins in the 3.25hr (0300-0615) since I made this forecast!
Need a surge of approx. 850 or more to pass 3000 tomorrow.

It has been outlined before. The probability to enroll many new members is low. There`s still the possibility of a black swan event, but given that the promotional machine is running since quite a while (I assume that there no hidden sign up incentive offered today or tomorrow - would enter the category of manipulation)  and I couldn´t find any incentives offered to join until Jan 08 and not later, it would be extraordinarily odd to surpass the 3000 threshold.

Currently 48hr (2d exactly) to go.  1 "normal" day, and 1 "surge" day. In past 24hr, 87 new forecasters.  (Rate of signup per hour in last 12hr has been more than double what it has been at any point in the last 3 days - a Friday evening effect??)
In 24hr before that, 64 new forecasters. 
In 24hr before that, 79 new forecasters. 
In 24hr before that, 167 new forecasters. 
In 24hr before _that_, 193 new forecasters. Assuming 70-80 new forecasters tomorrow, that would give us a total of 2164 to 2174 heading into the final 24hr "surge" ... which would then need to be 826 to 836 to meet a threshold of 3000+ forecasters.  1:8 odds of this happening.

2090 at 1:20 AM EST on 6 Jan 2018.
131 in past 41 hours, or 77 per 24 hours.
One more day at this rate will take us to approx. 2167.
Will we get 833 or more new forecasters on 7 January?
Hmmmm.
@dsarin regarding the surge... you make a really good point to not assume a lessor surge.  And @tsm -- the allure of the beautiful bridges make it hard to resist. Hedging a little.
I heard about this on a podcast that is pretty popular...alongside the CNN based promotion, I think a lot of people will join.

Currently 72hr (3d exactly) to go. 2 "normal" days, and 1 "surge" day. In past 24hr, 64 new forecasters.
In 24hr before that, 79 new forecasters.
In 24hr before that, 167 new forecasters.
In 24hr before _that_, 193 new forecasters. Assuming 60-80 new forecasters per day for each of the next 2 days, that would give us +120 to +160, for a total of 2127 to 2167 heading into the final 24hr "surge".

For your imagination, it's remarkable how similar the curve looks to a one side of some famous bridges (architecture), like the Golden Gate. What's more remarkable is, that quite a number of forecasters, me included, believe that the 2nd segment will be like the little-land-seated towers of the London Tower Bridge. https://10mosttoday.com/10-most-famous-bridges-in-the-world/  https://10mosttoday.com/10-most-famous-bridges-in-the-world/

I'm winding down on a daily basis to about 25/day but do wonder about the Sunday effect which I'm guessing @half of the original 1,100 so adding about 600 to a 25/day daily =  which equals around 2,700
But if the Sunday show adds more like 900 to that -- then it equals around 2,940
And there is that social media ad effect as well = ?
Watching for the Sunday (2 shows effect).  Is it half (550), or two thirds, or is it the same as the first Sunday effect (1,100) ? that could bring the total to over 3,000. Not sure.
I'm guessing that it's less than the first Sunday surge but either way, the total is really close.

Even with a surge of participants, the window is too small considering the number of current participants since the open.  The forecast over the next 4 days makes it unlikely that there will be a significant enough of an uptick in participants.

1959 at 8:50 AM EST on 4 Jan 2018.
119 in last 34 hours, so 84 in last 24 hours.
Rate is dropping a lot now. So let's say 75 per day for the next three days (including today). That would put us at 2184. It's possible to have another 1000+ on 7 January, but some of that viewership will be the same as last week, so I'm expecting less.
The majority of the uninterested population in such movement is far greater than those of us Whom du die the interest indeed.

Currently 96hr (4d exactly) to go.  3 "normal" days, and 1 "surge" day. In past 24hr, 79 new forecasters.
In 24hr before that, 167 new forecasters. 
In 24hr before _that_, 193 new forecasters. Assuming 60-80 new forecasters per day for each of the next 3 days, that would give us +180 to +240, for a total of 2123 to 2183 heading into the final 24hr "surge".

roughly 1500 added from jan 1 to today (I believe the month started with a couple or three hundred forecasters already on challenge and current count is 1900 +). Number increase today is very minimal - I think  people have already forgotten! Assuming another round of segments adds a similar  number to 1500, or lower as I'm guessing the numbers won't be radically higher or different for the next segment. Then we hit very close to 3000. The web ads might bump things up a bit

Currently 1935 forecasters at 2130 EST on 3 January.  Only 61 new forecasters in the last 15 hours (4.1/hr during US daytime).  77.5 "normal" hours to go. To fall into the "3000-4000" bracket, we would need to see MORE THAN: 
* 6.6 new forecasters/hr for each normal hour, and 
* a "surge" of 550 new forecasters on 7 Jan (that is, 50% of the surge on 31 Dec). Daytime should be a "peak recruitment" period, but instead there have been fewer recruits per hour today than there were _overnight_ two nights ago.  Hard to see recruitment topping 6/hr until the re-telecast on the 7th. Assuming a recruitment of 3.5/h for the next 77.5 hours, we would see 2206 forecasters by the time we start the "surge" day.  Could the surge day hit 800 new recruits???

Flipping forecast 66% under 3,000 and 34% over 3,000
2,015 (Jan 5, 8 am est).......+60 1,955 (Jan 4, 7:15 am est)..+28 98 new forecaster in last 24 hrs.
1,927 (Jan 3, 7 pm est).......+49 
1,878 (Jan 3, 7:12 am est)..+49 186 new forecasters in last 24 hrs, down from 240 for the prior 24 hrs 
1,829 (Jan 2, 7 pm est).....+115 
1,714 (Jan 2, 7:15 am est)..+71 Consistant over the past 24 hours, +240 new forecasters. 
1,643 (Jan 1, 7 pm est).....+121 
1,522 (Jan 1, 7 am est).....+119 
1,403 (Dec 31, 7 pm est) Simple upper limit projection: 3 days @50 : 150
Projection for end of day Jan. 6th: 1,927 + 150: 2,077 Jan 7 new forecaster projection: 
1) Duplicating Dec. 31 ( slightly under 1,100) the end of day Jan. 7th, number should be approx. 3,177. Based on 50 , new forecasters/day and plus a repeat of the Dec. 31 performance. 
2) If the daily sign-up rate averages 50 per day for the rest of the week and the Jan. 7 sign ups are at 50% of the Dec. 31 total (550 or 1,100/2), the end of day Jan 7th estimate is 2,627 (1,927+550+150). Adding an additional 40 for the first 10 hrs of Jan7, a low estimate of 2,667.
thinking previously aware forecasters joined first few days and join rate will be less for Jan 8th on-air segment,

Currently 120hr (5d exactly) to go.  4 "normal" days, and 1 "surge" day. In prior 24hr (0300 EST, 2 Jan; to 0300, 3 Jan), 167 new forecasters.
In 24hr before _that_, 193 new forecasters. Assuming 150 to 170 new forecasters per day for each of the next 4 days, that would give us +600 to +680, for a total of 2465 to 2545 heading into the final 24hr "surge". Wow, this really is too close to call. At this point, I am going to walk back to a more equivocal stake between "2001-2999" and "3000-4000".  I can favour one way or another as we get closer.  (Although, given the overwhelming importance of the unknowable  final "surge", I suspect I will be just as ambivalent with 24 hours to go!)

Currently 1853 forecasters at 2300 EST on 2 January.  29 new forecasters in the last 4 hours (7.3/hr during US evening). 102 "normal" hours to go. To fall into the "3000-4000" bracket, we would need to see MORE THAN: 
* 5.9 new forecasters/hr for each normal hour, and 
* a "surge" of 550 new forecasters on 7 Jan (that is, 50% of the surge on 31 Dec). *****************************
EDIT:

Because of latest press releases about members of the superforecasters group

1840 at 21:20 EST on 2 Jan 2018.
About 190 in past 24 hours. I was thinking an average of 100 per day after 31 Dec. Now it looks higher. Big question is still how many additional viewers will join on 7 Jan. It might be close.

Maintaining forecast @ 66% over 3,000 and 34% under 3,000 1,927 (Jan 3, 7 pm est).......+49
1,878 (Jan 3, 7:12 am est)..+49 186 new forecasters in last 24 hrs, down from 240 for the prior 24 hrs

Projection for end of day Jan. 6th: 1,829 + 600: 2,429 Jan 7 new forecaster projection: 
1) Duplicating Dec. 31 ( slightly under 1,100) the end of day Jan. 7th, number should be approx. 3,529.  Based on 150 , new forecasters/day and plus a repeat of the Dec. 31 performance. 
2) If the daily sign-up rate averages 100 per day for the rest of the week and the Jan. 7 sign ups are at 50% of the Dec. 31 total (550 or 1,100/2), the end of day Jan 7th estimate is 2,693 (1,643+550+500). Although it seems most estimates ignore the first 10 hrs of Jan. 7th, as they are not included in the approx. 1,100 recorded on 7th between 10am and midnight est. Adding an additional 40 for a low estimate of 2,733.

Currently 1809 forecasters at 1700 EST on 2 January.  106 new forecasters in the last 12 hours (8.8/hr during US daytime) - thanks to @praedico for helping to track this.  106 "normal" hours to go. To fall into the "1000-2000" bracket, we would really need to see the system crash, or some other calamity, as it would require only 1.5/hr and NO surge to reach 2001 forecasters. To fall into the "3000-4000" bracket, we would need to see MORE THAN: 
* 6.1 new forecasters/hr for each normal hour, and 
* a "surge" of 550 new forecasters on 7 Jan (that is, 50% of the surge on 31 Dec). It's reminding me very much of a run chase in a one-day game of cricket! *************************
EDIT:
Currently 1822 forecasters at 1800 EST, 2 January; +13 in last hour.
Television will reach a lot of interested candidates, but few will go through the effort of the introductory questionnaire.
thanks to @Ken_Barns and @praedico you give good rational bases for the judgement

1703 at 5:00 AM EST, 2 Jan 2018.
53 in last 9 hours. Rate is slowing, but not as much as I thought it would.

Currently 1699 forecasters at 0400 on 2 January.  42 new forecasters in the last 7 hours.  143 hours to go.  Let's split that into 119 "normal" hours, and the late "surge" 24 hours of the 7th of January. To fall into the "1000-2000" bracket, we would need to see FEWER THAN:
*  1.6 new forecasters/hr for each normal hour, and
*  a "surge" of 110 new forecasters on 7 January (that is, only 10% of the surge on 31 Dec). To fall into the "3000-4000" bracket, we would need to see MORE THAN:
*  6.3 new forecasters/hr for each normal hour, and
*  a "surge" of 550 new forecasters on 7 Jan (that is, 50% of the surge on 31 Dec).
I trust that enough people are concerned enough by politics to join this survey

So 5/hr overnight?  And 48 in the last 6 hrs (1500-2100 EST, 2 Jan), so 8/hr in the afternoon/evening of the day after the telecast ... which I imagine will drop further in the next couple of days. I estimate about 125 per day for each of the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th, and 6th = 625.  Add this to the current 1650, and we get 2275.  I think a 7 Jan "pulse" half the size of the 31 Dec pulse (ie. 0.5 * 1100 = 550) will be very ambitious, and still fall more than 150 short of the 3000-4000 bucket. However, I find it very difficult to see _not_ getting another 350 forecasters in 6 days.

Made primarily based upon the comments stating the most recent numbers. However, it depends on how many people join based upon word of mouth on the internet after TV spots. Facebook could tilt things to larger numbers.

1650 at 8:10 PM EST on 1 Jan 2018. 
157 new forecasters joined in the past 19 hours.
About 1100 joined on the day of the broadcast, 31 Dec 2017.
Started with about 400, adding at a rate of 28 per day independent of the broadcasts (+224). The big question is: How many more will join after the 7 Jan broadcast? Will it be like the 31 Dec broadcast, or have most interested viewers already joined? What percentage of the audience are viewers who didn't see the 31 Dec shows? That's going to make the difference between the 2000-3000 bucket and the 3000-4000 bucket.

Arbitrarily using 66% over 3,000 and 34% under 3,000 186 new forecasters in last 24 hrs, down from 240 for the prior 24 hrs
1,829 (Jan 2, 7 pm est).....+115
1,714 (Jan 2, 7:15 am est)..+71 Consistant over the past 24 hours, +240 new forecasters.
1,643 (Jan 1, 7 pm est).....+121
1,522 (Jan 1, 7 am est).....+119
1,403 (Dec 31, 7 pm est) Simple upper limit projection: 5 days @ 240 : 1,200
Projection for end of day Jan. 6th: 1,643 + 1,200: 2,843 Jan 7 new forecaster projection: 
1) Dec. 31 looks like the day's total was slightly under 1,100, if this is duplicated the end of day Jan. 7th, number should be approx. 3,943.  But is likely too high, as both the 240 new forecasters/day and a duplication of the Dec. 31 performance is required.
2) If the daily sign-up rate averages 100 per day for the rest of the week and the Jan. 7 sign ups are at 50% of the Dec. 31 total (550 or 1,100/2), the end of day Jan 7th estimate is 2,693 (1,643+550+500)

I read everyone else's answers where there was a rationale and an attempt at maths. That helped me eliminate the first option.  praedico's run rate for the days preceding the broadcast was helpful. And, it looks like a successful broadcast can deliver about 1000 extra entrants. I've assumed that it is less likely than even that other broadcasts will be as successful, so distributed the remaining likelihoods accordingly. Was heading to bed at the time so kept it simple and looked for shortcuts :)
I think the recall rate for an ad or short news segment generating signups after 2 airings in one day is pretty short
Yeah.  Given the early run, it is kind of a surprise that we are unlikely to reach 1500 by midnight. Now down to about 15/hr (= 350/d).

1461 at 9:50 PM EST, 31 Dec 2017. 1061 added today so far.
(ETA: 1493 at 1:10 AM EST 1 Jan 2018) GPS Challenge opened on 15 Dec. Had 400 forecasters this morning before the broadcast, so averaging  28 forecasters per day independent of broadcast. 28 x 8 more days = 224. 1461 + 224 = 1685 Remains to be seen how many additional forecasters join during the next week due to the broadcasts. Using a browser with no Google cookies, GJO comes up at the top of Google search results if I search for "good judgment", "good judgement", "judgment open", "forecasting competition", or "forecasting tournament". It is #3 if I search for "forecasting contest". It is #6 if I search for "judgment competition". It is not on the first page of search results if I search for "judgment contest". "Superforecasters" brings up a number of web pages related to Good Judgment Inc, but no direct link to the GJO. GJO is featured at the top of the Fareed Zakaria GPS web page, but it does not actually link to this site, as Zakaria says.  I don't think people will have trouble finding GJO if they don't remember exactly what it's called.

Rate of return declining now.  Looks like about 1400 at the moment, with 1000 having come from today.  Assume a lesser return (50%) on next Sunday, that gets us to about 1900. Baseline rate of joining GJC before telecast was about 25-30 per day.  Currently about 25/hr (= 600/d) and falling.  Let's say an average about about 100 per day over next 7 days.  Add that to 1900, gives 2600 total. What is needed for 4000?  Currently 7d and 7hr (= 175hr) remaining, and about 2550 new forecasters remaining.  That is about 15/hr ... sustained day and night.  Unlikely. What is needed for 3000?  About 9/hr (= 215/d) sustained over the next 7 days.  Today was a good day (which is not yet finished), that will likely wind up with about 1100.  Keeping 20% of that pace up for the next 7d is conceivable.
Expecting at least 2000 new forecasters to join independently of the show. The show will likely get a large number of people to join, even if they don't participate.
About 1000 added today so far (6:40 PM EST).

10 Baseline - 10% increase in joiners based on:
Average Rate of return on investment in terms of sales increase for multiplatform tv ads (ie. ads viewed on laptops, lcds, tvs phones for long-term ad campaigns ( 1 to 3 years). https://www.accenture.com/us-en/_acnmedia/PDF-18/Accenture-New-Insights-Into-Multiplatform-TV.pdf. Also personal experience,  with the amount of noise out there, it's extremely difficult to get a specific name to stick in memories of the 'consumer. "was that GGopen?" It does help that I can look up the CNN segment and view it online. 2) The GJOpen segment, 1minute 50 seconds, airs only four times over an eight-day period so  10% is probably very over-estimated. OTOH just joining a website is not as much of a commitment as parting with money for goods. Q-factor range: Fareed - I'd assume his is positive (versus negative impact on sales), 
but lower than average as his show is small subset of a large pool (all shows, all channels all days of the week.) Compare, for a baseline range,  to Oprah, an oulier with the  highest of all q-factors. Rate of return on Investment for a 7-minute segment on Oprah's favourite things during Christmas is several thousand percent return in terms of sales increase. 3) There was a direct call to action but it was about halfway through the segment so there is a risk people had tuned out by then and likely New Year's Eve there would be a lot of homey distractions, with family, party-prep, day-off pursuits, sleeping in (10 am), having lunch (1 pm), etc)   Also data supports around a 10 to 15 second attention span for ads so if the call to action appeared very early on I’d bump things up but not here.  Finally, its a big ask to get someone to remember the segment (and get the website name right),  go onto website, read the details and sign up. Jan 8th might have a better spike in numbers but I’m going with a around a 6% increase and max 10%.  Also remembering that there was a bump in numbers of around (2K? Not sure how many newbies that added)  this year based on GJopen being the topic on a German podcast. When all else fails ball park and estimate: a 3:41 segment generated around 5K new members and 1700 who generated one forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/652299) at a time when crowd forecasting was growing in awareness and popularity vs a 1:50 segment that was less detailed (less graphics and less WIIFM, so around half for a segment half as long --  2500 to 850. 
I estimate lower than the 2500-850 range as crowd- forecasting is fairly mature now so anyone who has an interest probably also has an awareness and so wouldn't be new to joining this website. This ad would have more luck if directed to school/colleges/universities but it's the holidays so likely not watching CNN as much this week. I read here somewhere (I think it was a post by @anneinak) that there are about 6000 of us forecasters but only about 340 or so active this year. 10% of 6K would be 600 or less new gjopeners with 400 leeway on the upside.

I do suspect however that his count for the EST is out by a couple of hours: see https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/659056. Perhaps he is using updates to edit, rather than doing a new forecast each time?  (Thus, the timestamp is for the original post, not any updates.) I am wondering whether this might have been a more useful exercise in forecasting if the question had been closed _before_ the initial FZ GPS telecast.  At the moment, this is less an exercise in forecasting, than an exercise in regularly tracking data as it comes in.

OK.  Ready for a flutter now.  Especially so as this question does not appear to be associated with any particular challenge, so we do not appear to have Accuracy points on the line that might sabotage our rankings in other challenges.  Most useful references have been those provided by @amory10 and @praedico in this thread: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/652299. Baseline is the previous segment in 2015.  From that, 5000 sign-ups and 1700 initial forecasts over 1 week. On this occasion, audience is likely to be about 60% higher.  Also, there seems to be an explicit invitation to join up, and promotion of the 5 specific questions being asked in the Global Judgement Challenge.  Numbers are likely to be higher, and conversion of sign-ups into forecast--makers is likely to be higher than the 33% in 2015. On that basis, maybe 6000 (an additional 20% over 2015, so actually a _lower_ percentage of the segment's audience) sign-ups, leading to maybe 2400 forecasts (assuming 40% conversion of sign-ups to forecasts).  Add this to the 400-odd forecasters already here (and increasing by about 50 per day in the last few days), and we get to about 3200 (2400 + 400 + [8*50]). I think this is being a bit conservative, if anything.  I think there is room for increased natural recruitment as the 2017 Challenges wind up, and people come across.  Also, I think there is good potential for a snowball effect: as the serious forecasters see how many "wild-and-crazy" forecasts are made by neophytes, the Global Judgement Challenge will become relatively easier to make a forecast that "beats the crowd", and thus more a more attractive source of Accuracy and "Brier vs Median" points. So, in reality, median result is about 3200, but more likely to be on the upside of that than the downside.  However, being a coward, I will nudge that downwards in deference to the Consensus Trend forecast of a median result somewhere in the 1000-1500 range.  That leaves a median result for my forecast in the 2500-3000 range, and a reasonably Gaussian spread around that point. DEFINITIONAL ISSUES?
Sure.  I am assuming the cut-off is at midnight precisely between the 7th and the 8th.  I can see potential to artificially inflate the figures if the answer is coming in just short of a threshold between one answer category and another. So ...
999- = 2%
1000-2000 = 18%
2001-2999 = 35%
3000-4000 = 30%
4001+ = 15% IMPLICATIONS?
Only a 20% chance (1:4 odds) that the outcome will be worse than the 2015 segment?  (That being 1700 new sign-ups + 400 current forecasters.)  Yeees, I think I can accept that. Only a 2% chance that (1:49 odds) that the GPS segment will result in less than _half_ of the new forecasts that the 2015 segment resulted in?  (That is, under 850 new + 400 current forecasts.)  Yes, I can live with that. Giving a 45% chance that the Global Judgement Challenge will become 3rd most-joined challenge (behind the Classic Geopolitical Challenge, and the Arab Strategy Forum, each of which contained questions open since September 2015)?  OK, I feel a little more uncomfortable about that.  On the other hand, weren't the much larger numbers in 2015, rather than the c.1000 active forecasters now, a testament to the original promotion in 2015? Ah well, it's all just a game, isn't it? Happy New Year all!
The sign-up procedures are pretty laborious, There will probably be many who check it out but abandon the effort before completing the survey and actually getting in.

Base rate: Opened Dec. 15th, 380 forecasters in 15 days is approx. 25 per day.
Base rate extrapolation: 8 additional days @ 25 / day is another 200 after Jan. 7th, 580 total. Another view: There are almost 6,200 forecasters on the GJP challenge, approx. 6% of this total (380) are forecasting on the GPS challenge after 15 days. CNN is promoting the challenge on New Year's Eve, then on Jan. 7th, the same day the Q closes.  May also be a slight delay as new forecasters digest Brier scores, etc.

Alternate Q: Which challenge will gain the most forecasters before 1/8? Current starting positions:
1) GJP - 6,158

So as of 30DEC17 there are a few challenges closing. These make for good comps; 1764, 2694, 1682, 4483, 6158.  Making a quick analysis we throw out the high and the low to get 1764, 2694, 4483 Summed= 8941 then divide by 3 = 2980  which just says what a typical challenge should do after 1 year.  However, is this case different? Yes. There are only 384 forecasters at this time.  Best guess would be to make the 2980 an upper limit.
